body:
When you were a kid, you might have been afraid of things that go bump in the night. But what about things that go "pop"?

Believe it or not, some people are terrified of balloons. Globophobia, as psychologists term it, usually stems from a bad childhood experience with a popping balloon.

Think that's strange? Psychologists have a name for just about every phobia you can imagine. For example, some people suffer from coulrophobia, the fear of clowns, while others, pupaphobes, fear puppets. Those who suffer from consecotaleophobia are afraid of manipulating chopsticks, while those who suffer from anablephobia are afraid of looking up. And here's one that will keep you on your feet: kathisophobia, the fear of sitting.

Psychologists have unique names for fears of individual numbers and each letter of the alphabet. And clearly a sadist coined the fear of long words: hippopotomonstrosesquipedaliophobia.
title: A Phobia For Everyone

senses.difference: impressed with fear or apprehension; in fear; apprehensive
colloquially, express sorrow
Not good; unfavorable; negative.
senses.example: You have bad credit.

senses.difference: Seemingly non-appropriate, in manners, etc.
senses.example: It is bad manners to talk with your mouth full.

senses.difference: Not suitable or fitting.
tricky; stressful; unpleasant
senses.example: Divorce is usually a bad experience for everybody involved.

senses.difference: evil, wicked
senses.example: Be careful. There are bad people in the world.

senses.difference: faulty; not functional
senses.example: I had a bad headlight.

senses.difference: Of food, spoilt, rotten, overripe.
Of breath, malodorous, foul.
bold and daring
serious; urgent
Relating to a single person or thing as opposed to more than one.
senses.example: As we can't print them all together, the individual pages will have to be printed one by one.

senses.difference: Intended for a single person as opposed to more than one person.
senses.example: individual personal pension; individual cream cakes

senses.difference: having much distance from one point to another
Having great duration.
senses.example: The pyramids of Egypt have been around for a long time.

senses.difference: Not normal; odd, unusual, surprising, out of the ordinary.
senses.example: He thought it strange that his girlfriend wore shorts in the winter.

senses.difference: not yet part of one’s experience
in quantum mechanics
In, on, or at this place.
To this place.
away from earth’s centre
Into pieces.
senses.example: tear up

senses.difference: An abstract adverb of motion or change.
senses.example: mess up

senses.difference: for emphasis
rail transport: the direction towards milepost zero
(cricket) Relatively close to the batsman.
senses.example: The bowler pitched the ball up.

senses.difference: Used to make a suggestion.
senses.example: What about going to a restaurant tonight?

senses.difference: Used to ask someone to consider something or someone that they have apparently not considered.
senses.example: You're obviously having a good time, but what about me?

senses.difference: Definite grammatical article that implies necessarily that the entity it articulates is presupposed; something already mentioned, or completely specified later in the same sentence, or assumed already completely specified. Compare I’m reading a book with
senses.example: The street in front of your house. (But compare a street in Paris)

senses.difference: stressed, indicating that the object in question is the only one worthy of attention
With an adjectival noun, as in “the hungry” to mean “hungry people”
With a superlative, it refers to the same thing which the superlative applies to.
senses.example: That apple pie was the best.

senses.difference: Used as an alternative to a possessive pronoun before body parts
Used with the name of a member of a class to refer to all things in that class
To know how to; to be able to.
senses.example: She can speak English, French, and German.

senses.difference: May; to be permitted or enabled to.
senses.example: You can go outside and play when you're finished with your homework.

senses.difference: Used to indicate conditional or possible actions.
senses.example: I might go to the party, but I haven't decided yet.

senses.difference: Used to indicate permission in simple past tense.
senses.example: He asked me if he might go to the party, but I haven't decided yet.

senses.difference: Used to connect two similar words, phrases, et cetera
Used at the end of a list to indicate the last item.
senses.example: bread, butter and cheese

senses.difference: Used to string together sentences or sentence fragments in chronological order
Used to show causation
In the same way that; according to what.
senses.example: As you wish, my lord!

senses.difference: At the same instant that; when.
senses.example: As I came in, she flew.

senses.difference: At the same time that; while.
senses.example: He sleeps as the rain falls.

senses.difference: Varying through time to the same proportion that.
senses.example: As the fear grew, my legs became heavier.

senses.difference: Considering that, because, since.
senses.example: As it’s too late, I quit.

senses.difference: in the manner of
Except (for), excluding.
senses.example: I like everything but that. I have no choice but to leave.

senses.difference: On the contrary, but rather (introducing a word or clause that contrasts with or contradicts the preceding clause or sentence without the not).
senses.example: I am not rich but poor.

senses.difference: However, although, nevertheless (implies that the following clause is contrary to prior belief or contrasts with or contradicts the preceding clause or sentence).
senses.example: She is very old but still attractive. You told me I could do that but she said that I could not.

senses.difference: During the same time that.
senses.example: He was sleeping while I was singing.

senses.difference: although
senses.example: This case, while interesting, is a bit frustrating.

senses.difference: every one; every thing
senses.example: I'm going to give each of you a chance to win.

senses.difference: For one; per
senses.example: The apples cost 50 cents each.

senses.difference: inflatable object
Such an object as a child’s toy.
inflatable object to transport people through the air
(medicine) A sac inserted into part of the body for therapeutic reasons; such as angioplasty.
A light blow or jolting collision.
The sound of such a collision.
A protuberance on a level surface.
A swelling on the skin caused by illness or injury.
(rowing) The point, in a race in which boats are spaced apart at the start, at which a boat begins to overtake the boat ahead.
The swollen abdomen of a pregnant woman.
(internet) A post in an Internet forum thread made in order to raise the thread's profile by returning it to the top of the list of active threads.
(uncountable) The state of being a child.
time when one is a child
(''by extension'') the early stages of development of something
performance artist working in a circus
person acting in a silly fashion
Event(s) of which one is cognizant.
Activity which one has performed.
Collection of events and/or activities from which an individual or group may gather knowledge, opinions, and skills.
The knowledge thus gathered.
uncountable: emotion caused by actual or perceived danger or threat
a phobia; sense of fear induced by something or someone
(uncountable) Extreme veneration or awe, as toward a supreme being or deity.
part of animal’s body {{jump|t|body part
part of human body {{jump|t|human body part
bottom of anything  {{jump|t|base
projection on equipment {{jump|t|support
unit of measure {{jump|t|unit of length|u|co
measure of rhythm {{jump|t|measure of rhythm
bottom edge of a sail {{jump|t|bottom edge of a sail
A young goat.
Kidskin.
A young antelope.
child (colloq.)
young person (colloq.)
letter of the alphabet
A written message. See also note.
senses.example: I wrote a letter to my sister about my life.

senses.difference: word or phrase indicating a particular person, place, class or thing
Reputation.
(countable) The period between sunset and sunrise, when a location faces far away from the sun, thus when the sky is dark.
(countable) An evening or night spent at a particular activity.
senses.example: a night on the town

senses.difference: night spent at a hotel
(countable) The quality of sleep obtained during a night.
senses.example: I had a bad night last night.

senses.difference: (uncountable) Nightfall.
senses.example: from noon till night

senses.difference: (uncountable) Darkness.
senses.example: The cat disappeared into the night.

senses.difference: (countable) An abstract entity used to describe quantity.
senses.example: Zero, one, -1, 2.5, and pi are all numbers.

senses.difference: {{context|Followed by a numeral; used attributively}} Indicating the position of something in a list or sequence. Abbreviations: No or No., no or no. (in each case, sometimes written with a superscript "o", like Nº or №). The symbol "#" is also use
senses.example: Horse number 5 won the race.

senses.difference: mathematical number
used to show the rank of something in a list or sequence
Quantity.
senses.example: Any number of people can be reading from a given repository at a time

senses.difference: grammar: state of being singular, dual or plural
(countable) A performance; especially, a single song or song and dance routine within a larger show.
senses.example: For his second number, he sang "The Moon Shines Bright".

senses.difference: a body of human beings; a group of two or more persons
a group of persons forming or belonging to a particular nation etc.
a group of persons regarded as being employees etc.
A person's ancestors, relatives or family.
senses.example: My people lived through the Black Plague and the Thirty Years War.

senses.difference: the mass of community as distinguished from a special class
(countable) A loud, sharp sound as of a cork coming out of a bottle.
senses.example: Listen to the pop of a Champagne cork.

senses.difference: (context|uncountable|colloquial) an effervescent or fizzy drink most frequently nonalcoholic; soda pop.
movable model of a person or animal
person or country controlled by another
a separate entity or concept
any physical or psychical entity
In Scandinavian countries, a legislative or judicial assembly.
A distinct unit of language which is approved by some authority.
Something promised.
senses.example: I give you my word that I will be there on time.

senses.difference: computing sense
{{theology|sometimes Word}} God.
the word of God
Towards.
senses.example: The astronauts headed for the moon.

senses.difference: Directed at, intended to belong to.
senses.example: I have something for you.

senses.difference: Supporting (opposite of against).
senses.example: All those for the motion raise your hands.

senses.difference: Because of.
senses.example: He wouldn't apologize; and just for that, she refused to help him.

senses.difference: With the source or provenance of or at.
senses.example: This wine comes from France.

senses.difference: With the origin, starting point or initial reference of or at.
senses.example: He had books piled from floor to ceiling.

senses.difference: With the separation, exclusion or differentiation of.
senses.example: An umbrella protects from the sun.

senses.difference: Contained by.
senses.example: The dog is in the kennel.

senses.difference: Surrounded by.
senses.example: We are in the enemy camp.

senses.difference: part, member of
Pertaining to (that particular thing).
senses.example: He has passed in English.

senses.difference: After a period of time.
senses.example: They said they would call us in a week.

senses.difference: by the virtue of
Into.
senses.example: Less water gets in your boots this way.

senses.difference: Belonging to or associated with.
senses.example: The properties of this substance are interesting. <!-- Belonging to (better example?) -->

senses.difference: containing, comprising or made from
about the old days
connects a quantifier with quantified
{{non-gloss definition|Connects a noun derived from a verb with the object of that verb.}}
senses.example: Some resisted the admission of the new members to the club.

senses.difference: (''time'') before
connecting a jurisdiction to its name
indicative of age
Positioned at the upper surface of, touching from above.
senses.example: on the table; on the couch

senses.difference: covering
At the date of.
senses.example: Born on the 4th of July.

senses.difference: Dealing with the subject of, about, or concerning something.
senses.example: A book on history.

senses.difference: Touching; hanging from.
senses.example: The fruit ripened on the trees.

senses.difference: math:having ''V'' as both domain and codomain
math:having ''V''<sup>n</sup> as domain and ''V'' as codomain
Because of, or due to something.
senses.example: To arrest someone on suspicion of bribery.

senses.difference: Paid for by.
senses.example: The drinks are on me tonight, boys.

senses.difference: used to indicate means or medium
against
senses.example: He picked a fight with the class bully.

senses.difference: in the company of; alongside, along side of; close to; near to:
senses.example: He went with his friends.

senses.difference: in addition to; as an accessory to:
senses.example: She owns a motorcycle with a sidecar.

senses.difference: in support of:
senses.example: We are with you all the way.

senses.difference: expressing manner
as an instrument; by means of
senses.example: cut with a knife

senses.difference: (obsolete) as nourishment, more recently replaced by on
subject — inanimate thing
The impersonal pronoun, used as a placeholder for a delayed subject, or less commonly, object.
senses.example: It is easy to see how she would think that.

senses.difference: subject of impersonal statement
{{context|impersonal pronoun}} one thing (among a group of others); one member of a group
senses.example: The big one looks good.

senses.difference: {{context|indefinite personal pronoun}} any person (applying to people in general)
senses.example: One shouldn’t be too quick to judge.

senses.difference: who? (interrogative pronoun)
who (relative pronoun)
subject pronoun: the person being addressed
object pronoun: the person being addressed
subject pronoun: the group being addressed
object pronoun: the group being addressed
{{i|subject pronoun}} Anyone, one; an unspecified individual.
senses.example: You have to be at least 36 inches high to go on this ride.

senses.difference: belonging to you (singular; one owner)
belonging to you (plural; more owners)
belonging to you (to be sorted)
(intransitive) To occupy a place.
senses.example: The cup is on the table.

senses.difference: occur, take place
{{intransitive|without predicate}} To exist.
senses.example: The meaning of life, or how we have come to be.

senses.difference: elliptical form of "be here", or similar
(transitive|copulative) Used to indicate that the subject and object are the same.
senses.example: Ignorance is bliss.

senses.difference: (transitive|copulative|mathematics) Used to indicate that the values on either side of an equation are the same.
senses.example: 3 times 5 is fifteen.

senses.difference: used to indicate that the subject plays the role of the predicate nominative
(transitive|copulative) Used to connect a noun to an adjective that describes it.
senses.example: The sky is blue.

senses.difference: (transitive|copulative) Used to indicate that the subject has the qualities described by a noun or noun phrase.
senses.example: The sky is a deep blue today.

senses.difference: (context|transitive|auxiliary) Used to form the passive voice.
senses.example: The dog was drowned by the boy.

senses.difference: (context|transitive|auxiliary) Used to form the continuous forms of various tenses.
senses.example: The woman is walking.

senses.difference: (archaic) Used to form the perfect aspect with certain intransitive verbs. Often still used for to go
senses.example: They are not yet come back. (Macbeth by William Shakespeare) (instead of They have not yet come back.)

senses.difference: (context|transitive|auxiliary) Used to form future tenses, especially the future subjunctive.
senses.example: I am to leave tomorrow.

senses.difference: Used to indicate age.
senses.example: This building is three hundred years old.

senses.difference: Used to indicate height.
senses.example: He was five-eight.

senses.difference: Used to indicate time of day, day of the week, or date.
senses.example: It is almost eight.

senses.difference: (often|impersonal) Used to indicate weather, air quality, or the like.
senses.example: It’s hot in Arizona, but it’s not usually humid.

senses.difference: (rfv-sense) Used to indicate temperature.
senses.example: It’s in the eighties outside, and next week it’s expected to be in the nineties! (Fahrenheit degrees)

senses.difference: to accept that someone is telling the truth (object: person)
(transitive) To accept as true.
senses.example: * If you believe the numbers, you'll agree we need change.

senses.difference: (transitive) To consider likely.
senses.example: * I believe it might rain tomorrow.(This definition is the same as "to accept as true", but for a likely event "might rain tomorrow").

senses.difference: (intransitive) To have religious faith; to believe in a greater truth.
senses.example: * After that night in the church, I believed.{This definition should be disregarded as it is the same as the transitive "to accept as true"}.

senses.difference: to create coins.
to make up or invent, and establish
senses.example: Over the last century the advance in science has led to many new words being coined.

senses.difference: (transitive) To feel fear about (something).
senses.example: I fear the worst will happen.

senses.difference: (transitive) To venerate; to feel awe towards.
senses.example: People who fear God can be found in Christian churches.

senses.difference: to move from a place to another that is further away {{jump|t|move|s|a
to disappear {{jump|t|disappear|s|a
to be destroyed {{jump|t|collapse|s
of a machine, to work {{jump|t|function|s
to fit {{jump|t|fit|s
to have as its/their proper place {{jump|t|belong in a place|s
to take a turn {{jump|t|take a turn|s
to urinate {{jump|t|urinate|s
to date {{jump|t|date|s
to make (a specified sound) {{jump|t|make a sound
slang: to say {{jump|t|say
to become {{jump|t|become|s
(transitive) To possess, own, hold.
senses.example: I have a house and a car.

senses.difference: to be related to
to partake of something
auxiliary used in forming the perfect and the past perfect tenses
{{context|auxiliary verb, taking a to-infinitive}} must.
senses.example: I have to go.

senses.difference: (transitive) To give birth to.
senses.example: The couple always wanted to have children.

senses.difference: (transitive) To engage in sexual intercourse with.
senses.example: He's always bragging about how many women he's had.

senses.difference: cause to, by command or request
(transitive with adjective or adjective-phrase complement) To cause to be.
senses.example: She had him arrested for trespassing.

senses.difference: (transitive with bare infinitive) To be affected by an occurrence. (Used in supplying a topic that is not a verb argument.)
senses.example: The hospital had several patients contract pneumonia last week.

senses.difference: (transitive with adjective or adjective-phrase complement) To depict as being.
senses.example: Their stories differed; he said he'd been at work when the incident occurred, but her statement had him at home that entire evening.

senses.difference: Used as interrogative auxiliary verb with a following pronoun to form tag questions. (For further discussion, see "Usage notes" below)
senses.example: We haven't eaten dinner yet, have we?

senses.difference: (transitive) To form a mental image of something; to envision or create something in one's mind.
senses.example: Try to imagine a pink elephant.

senses.difference: (transitive) To believe in something created by one's own mind.
senses.example: She imagined that the man wanted to kill her.

senses.difference: (transitive) To assume.
senses.example: I imagine that he will need to rest after such a long flight.

senses.difference: (transitive) To conjecture or guess.
senses.example: I cannot even imagine what you are up to!

senses.difference: (intransitive) To use one's imagination.
senses.example: Imagine that we were siblings

senses.difference: (intransitive) To guess or conjecture.
senses.example: Let me imagine - it's a ring!

senses.difference: (transitive) To maintain possession of.
senses.example: I keep a small stock of painkillers for emergencies.

senses.difference: to maintain the condition of; to preserve
(transitive|archaic) To remain in, to be confined to.
(transitive) To restrain.
senses.example: I keep my brother out of trouble by keeping him away from his friends and hard at work. <!-- The first "keep" here does not have the "restrain" sense, so it shouldn't be in bold. -->

senses.difference: (intransitive) To continue.
senses.example: I keep taking the tablets, but to no avail.

senses.difference: (intransitive|cricket) To act as wicket-keeper.
senses.example: Godfrey Evans kept for England for many years.

senses.difference: of livestock: to raise; to care for
{{intransitive|often|with "at"}} To try to see, to pay attention to with one’s eyes.
senses.example: Look at my new car!

senses.difference: To appear, to seem.
senses.example: It looks as if it’s going to rain soon.

senses.difference: {{intransitive|often|with "for"}} To search for, to try to find.
To face or present a view.
senses.example: The hotel looks over the valleys of the HinduKush.

senses.difference: To expect or anticipate.
senses.example: I look to each hour for my lover’s arrival.

senses.difference: (ergative) to burst something
senses.example: The boy with the pin popped the balloon.

senses.difference: to act suddenly, unexpectedly or quickly.
of a person, be in a position in which the upper body is upright and the legs are supported
{{intransitive|of a person}} To move oneself into such a position.
senses.example: I asked him to sit.

senses.difference: of an object: occupy a given position permanently
(government) To be a member of a deliberative body.
senses.example: I currently sit on a standards committee.

senses.difference: of an agreement or arrangement, to be accepted
To descend in a family line.
To be caused or derived; to originate.
senses.example: The current crisis stems from the short-sighted politics of the previous government.

senses.difference: To take out the stem from something.
To stop, hinder (for instance, a river or blood).
skiing: to point the skis inward
(intransitive) To undergo hardship.
(intransitive) To feel pain.
senses.example: At least he didn't suffer when he died in the car crash.

senses.difference: {{context|intransitive|construed with from}} To have a disease or condition.
senses.example: He's suffering from the flu this week.

senses.difference: (intransitive) To become worse.
senses.example: If you keep partying like this, your school-work will suffer.

senses.difference: (transitive) To endure, undergo.
senses.example: I've been suffering your insults for years.

senses.difference: (context|transitive|archaic) To allow.
To frighten greatly; to fill with terror.
To menace or intimidate.
(transitive) to ponder, to go over in one's head
senses.example: Idly, the detective thought what his next move should be.

senses.difference: communicate to oneself in one’s mind
(intransitive) to conceive of something or someone (usually followed by of or on)
senses.example: I tend to think of her as rather ugly.

senses.difference: (transitive) To be of the opinion (that).
senses.example: I think she is pretty, contrary to most people.

senses.difference: guess, reckon
consider, judge, regard something as
